Latest prison reforms will cause more harm than good

04/05/2013

A successful penal system should be weighted towards rehabilitation; making sure that prisoners don't get trapped in the revolving door of re-offending.

Image by

By undefined undefined

The justice secretary Chris Gayling recently announced reforms to the prison system's Incentives and Earned Privilege scheme (IEP). The most significant change will reduce the levels of privileges prisoners have during their first two weeks at prison. Currently the UK's prisons have a three tier system of comfort that prisoners' can be at: basic, standard and enhanced. These are mainly there to reward inmates who are well-behaved and cooperative, and discipline those that aren't. The recent changes introduce a new 'entry' level class for new in-mates, lying in-between basic and standard. Prisoners will have to wear standard issue clothes for their first few weeks and will have reduced access to private cash for phone calls home. Also, movement up the levels will now require'positive engagement' rather than simply an absence of bad behaviour. The general public often hold a vengeful lynch-mob mentality about prisoners, and what's done with them. But it's important not to get sucked into this cloud of ignorance; if you do then the reforms start to seem like a good idea. But really, the prison population should be viewed through a (perhaps quite thin) lens of empathy. A study by NICE estimated that up to 90 per cent of prisoners have some form of diagnosable mental health issue and 70 per cent of these have a drug problem. Suicide rates in prisons can be up to 15 times higher than outside. A huge number of offenders come from broken families and experienced abuse as children. Of course, the first few weeks of prison for these generally mentally unstable people is the most stressful, where they're most likely to be targeted by bullies, and when they're at the highest risk of self-harm and suicide. For these reasons, it is the change saying that prisoners have to wear 'standard-issue' clothes for the first two weeks that has been highlighted by wardens and ex-convicts as one that is most dangerous. It will mark them out as vulnerable new inmates, ripe for bullying, by highlighting them clearly among the existing prison population. This could potentially worsen underlying psychological problems. And as well as this clothing change, the change of restricting cash for calls in the first few weeks has also been highlighted as being dangerous as helping to make it overly difficult for prisoners to settle in the most difficult period of incarceration. Some people might protest: these are convicted criminals; so what if they're bullied and singled out early on, why does it matter that their calls home are restricted? Prison should be as horrible as possible, right? It is true that prison is meant to be a punishment, but the fact that they're locked up in a compound for months or years is really punishment enough - the complete restriction of their liberty. Even if you're callous enough to think that prisoners' deserve all of what they get from these new changes, there's a pragmatic reason to disagree with the reforms. According to the most recent figures from the Ministry of Justice, more than one in four criminals re-offended within a year and the rough figure of a 25 per cent re-offending rate has been at this high level for around a decade. Obviously, this offending rate is incredibly costly for society monetarily and socially. It is a mistake to introduce any changes that could destabilise prisoners' long term progress by potentially making them more mentally unstable from the start. A successful penal system should be weighted towards rehabilitation; making sure that prisoners don't get trapped in the revolving door of re-offending. But to do this, prisons will have to be more 'cosy' than perhaps most people would like, especially in the first few weeks. New inmates should be allowed to settle in and come to terms with their situation. If their first few weeks are overly traumatic, the tedious and fragile process of rehabilitation might be compromised. Although these changes look anything but sensible, what's more important is the opportunity that's been missed here. Instead of focusing on making the IEP scheme harsher, changes should really have been directed at making rehabilitation more effective. However, improving rehabilitation is best done by spending more money on it (well, in theory), and obviously the government isn't in the right place at the moment to be able to do this. In this respect, you can see why these IEP reforms have been announced; it won't cost much to change the terms and conditions of this scheme. But of course change isn't always for the better, especially not when it's merely a cynical ploy to win over voters.
